channel.title: EasyRSC–Run on Macs & Linux
channel.description:
Hello! I do not develop with RSC private servers, but I made a guide for those on Mac/Linux to run EasyRSC.
[size=12pt]First go to http://www.moparisthebest.com/smf/index.php/topic,340170.0.html (a stickied thread) and download EasyRSC.[/size]
1. To run the client, type in "cd " (no quotes, but include the space) and the directory of your "Client" folder. The "cd" stands for "change directory". Pretty self explanatory, eh? 2. Next, press enter. 3. Lastly, type "ant run client" and press enter to run the client. Example: [img]http://i53.tinypic.com/nprui0.png[/img]
1. To run the server, type in "cd " and the director of your "Server" folder. 2. Next, press enter. 3. Lastly, type "ant runserver" and press enter to run the server. Example: [img]http://oi54.tinypic.com/nlzred.jpg[/img]
Good luck Unix OS users!
TheCyberMan
P.S. [quote="RSCShadow"]Most Linux distributions don't even come with Apache Ant.
For Debian-based distros (with the correct repo installed), type: [code]sudo apt-get install ant[/code] Before you run any "ant" commands.[/quote] [img]http://i53.tinypic.com/1znoro2.png[/img]

item.title: EasyRSC–Run on Macs & Linux
item.dc:creator: @TheCyberMan TheCyberMan
item.description:
@TheCyberMan wrote:

Thank you for that information. I updated my post including your quote.

item.title: EasyRSC–Run on Macs & Linux
item.dc:creator: @TheCyberMan TheCyberMan
item.description:
@TheCyberMan wrote:

Hello! I do not develop with RSC private servers, but I made a guide for those on Mac/Linux to run EasyRSC.

[size=12pt]First go to http://www.moparisthebest.com/smf/index.php/topic,340170.0.html (a stickied thread) and download EasyRSC.[/size]

  1. To run the client, type in "cd " (no quotes, but include the space) and the directory of your “Client” folder. The “cd” stands for “change directory”. Pretty self explanatory, eh?

  2. Next, press enter.

  3. Lastly, type “ant run client” and press enter to run the client.
    Example:

  4. To run the server, type in "cd " and the director of your “Server” folder.

  5. Next, press enter.

  6. Lastly, type “ant runserver” and press enter to run the server.
    Example:

Good luck Unix OS users!

TheCyberMan

P.S. [quote=“RSCShadow”]Most Linux distributions don’t even come with Apache Ant.

For Debian-based distros (with the correct repo installed), type:

sudo apt-get install ant

Before you run any “ant” commands.[/quote]

1znoro2.png1139×483

Read full topic
